intro: Elleanthus graminifolius, commonly known as the grass-leaf elleanthus, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to specific regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves that are typically narrow and linear, with a smooth, sometimes hairy surface. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in dense clusters, usually at the tips of the stems. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in open grasslands or rocky outcrops. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
